docs.lead_paragraph: IN the Christmas season, when the needs of the poor, the sick and the troubled are most keenly felt, charitable agencies, not-for-profit family service groups and spiritually motivated people on Long Island are responding. Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, the largest single charitable organization in a region where about half of all residents are Catholic, is offering gifts, emergency food and even money.

headline.main: Charities Are Responding to Extra Holiday Needs

docs.abstract: Charities on Long Island are responding to extra Christmas holiday needs, including offering gifts, emergency food and money to the needy (M)
docs.snippet: IN the Christmas season, when the needs of the poor, the sick and the troubled are most keenly felt, charitable agencies, not-for-profit family service groups and spiritually motivated people on Long Island are responding.    Catholic Charities of...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE people who work at the Columbia/ HCA division office in Winter Park, Fla., watch what they say to one another. They self-consciously do not speak of the Government's huge fraud investigation of their company or anything related to it. They know that any colleague they talk to might at some point be subpoenaed and that any conversation -- even their jokes -- could end up being regurgitated before a grand jury. So goes work when the law is peeking in the window. Like many other employees, Trudi Kirby, a nurse supervisor at Columbia Park Medical Center in Orlando, Fla., no longer wears her Columbia T-shirts to the gym or the Target food store. She can do without being hectored as she assesses the broccoli. ''You get this, 'Oh, you're the one who took all that money,' '' she said. ''I can't make them realize that it's not me, it's not this hospital.'' She saves the shirts for gardening and slumber.

headline.main: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT: Working Under a Cloud -- A special report.; How Scandal Put an End To the Flag-Waving

docs.abstract: Special Report: Working Under a Cloud discusses adverse impact of Government's huge fraud investigation of Columbia/HCA on company, its employees, its hospitals and their staffs; notes investigation has resulted in such things as hospital employees being hectored in stores with allegations of corruption to layoffs at Columbia's corporate headquarters in Nashville, resulting in increased anxiety among company's 285,000 employees; efforts of Thomas F Frist Jr, recently appointed chief executive of Columbia/HCA, to restore Columbia's reputation discussed; photos; graph traces 12 months of problems at Columbia/HCA (L)

byline.original: By KURT EICHENWALD and N. R. KLEINFIELD

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In your article ''The Fitness Gurus'' (Nov. 30), Kevin Sagafi, the chief operating officer of the New York Health and Racquet Club, is quoted as saying, ''In the future, insurance companies are going to work with health clubs to make sure their clients are staying healthy.'' At present, a number of health plans already offer a reimbursement benefit to their members for simple attendance at their health club. The criteria are based on the number of days attended. The amount reimbursed can be as much as $150, paid semiannually. Membership sales at the clubs owned by these ''gurus'' have been helped by this new health care benefit.

headline.main: Pumping Pencils; Insurers Already Started To Reimburse Gym Fees

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S time for that annual rite, your child's yearly checkup. After the weigh-in, the measuring and the twisting of joints, the underwear-clad child pops the dreaded question: Am I getting a shot? Well, you mumble, just your annual anthrax booster. Anthrax?

headline.main: The Nation; The Shots Heard 'Round the World

docs.abstract: Article focuses on decision by US Defense Department to inoculate entire military against use of anthrax as biological warfare agent; says all Americans should be inoculated against its potential use in military or terrorist attack; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: RICHARD FRANCHELLA, 37, a senior vice president at Prudential Securities in New York, wishes that he and his parents had discussed the family's finances sooner. Not quite two years ago, his father, a retired factory worker who lives in Port Chester, N.Y., was paralyzed by a stroke at 60. Acute diabetes had been diagnosed in his mother in 1993 when she was 55. Mr. Franchella said he was startled to learn that his parents had inadequate health insurance and were not financially prepared to retire.

headline.main: Taking Time to Unwrap The Family Finances

docs.abstract: Financial planners offer suggestions to get families started on discussing strategies that will help insure and protect savings in event of medical and other expenses; chart on some books on financial planning (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If he felt sure that his employer would not shuffle him to a meaningless job or, worse, invent grounds to dismiss him, an internist at a Brooklyn hospital said he would be candid about being infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. If he knew that his patients and colleagues would respond solely based on scientific data and experience, an ophthalmologist from a Midwestern state said he would also be willing to talk about the fact that he is H.I.V. positive.

headline.main: Medical Workers With H.I.V. Keep Silent, Fearing Reprisals

docs.abstract: Doctors and other health-care professionals infected with HIV keep that information to themselves, fearing that to reveal it would cost them their jobs; experts agree that their concerns are well founded because the public fears infection by a health-care professional despite overwhelming scientific and epidemiological evidence that proper precautions eliminate virtually all risk of transmitting virus (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A NEW set of companies is hoping that more dentists will do what many doctors are already doing: have someone else manage their businesses. Facing a mountain of administrative and marketing tasks, an increasing number of doctors in the last four years have turned to physician practice-management companies, or P.P.M.'s, for help. Now, 3 percent to 10 percent of all doctors use them.

headline.main: Pain or Gain From Dental Management?

docs.abstract: Number of dental practice-management companies have started in last two years, with five of these concerns going public since beginning of this year; stakes are huge, with Americans spending $46 billion a year on dentistry; one difficulty, however, is that dentistry is very fragmented profession, with about 70 percent of dentists, and about 60 percent of orthodontists, in solo practice; American Dental Association has neither approved nor disapproved of use of management companies, but some dentists are beginning to embrace them; photo; chart on some dental management companies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Laurie Barry went for her yearly physical examination in Lake Success, her doctor recommended that she have a bone density test, because she was older than 40 and had a family history of osteoporosis. Formerly, Ms. Barry would have scheduled an appointment at a testing center. But now she walked down the hall. Last year, soon after Judy Bowness had moved to Long Island because her husband became head coach of the Islanders, she broke her foot and needed an orthopedist. Within months her son developed migraine headaches, her daughter broke her wrist, and Mrs. Bowness needed physical therapy for her wrist, as well as a bone scan.
docs.abstract: Prohealth Care Associates, limited liability partnership of 60 doctors in Lake Success, NY, allows doctors to focus on care while a company, Prohealth Corp, runs the business side, leading to efficient office management and reduced waiting times; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In another jolt to the health insurance business, shares in Aetna Inc., one of the largest health insurers, plunged nearly 12 percent yesterday after the company announced the abrupt departure of a key financial executive. The swoon took $1.4 billion in stock market value from the company in a matter of hours. Stock analysts, who had been as surprised as anyone, began backing away from recommendations to invest.
docs.abstract: Resignation of Aetna Inc's financial executive James H Dickerson Jr sends company's stock down nearly 12 percent; stock drops $9.375, to $69.50; analysts say resignation raises prospect that a second quarter of disappointing earnings looms (L)
